elements.content: This study has developed a simple and innovative approach to design a metal–organic framework (MOF) with tunable conductivity. The in situ amine functionalized TMU-60 [Zn­(OBA)­(L*)·DMF] has the potential of converting to a conductor due to the selective and fast sorption of cadmium ion. In order to precisely monitor the cadmium penetration to the framework pores, in addition to full kinetic and thermodynamic studies of sorption, the time-dependent effects of Cd­(II) penetration to MOF pores was taken by fluorescence and electrochemical methods. The results obviously prove that the conductivity of the structure can be adjusted by changing the Cd exposure time and the quantity of ion sorption. The presence of cadmium ions can enhance the ability of the framework to pass electrons through its constituents. Even though the porosity of the structure remains to a certain extent, the achieved tunable and highly stable electrical conductivity is provided by sorption of metal ions. More importantly, the conductivity has been improved from 53 × 10–6 to 1.8 × 10–2 S·cm–1 for TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd compressed pellet (room temperature), respectively. The mechanism of charge transport through the pellet is proposed to be a hopping mechanism between metal nodes and localized Cd­(II) after sorption, which is supported by chronoamperometry measurement. A fit of the time-dependent data to the Cottrell equation gave a charge-transport diffusion coefficient of 1.6 × 10–10 cm2/s throughout the structure. This novel approach not only enhances the conductivity of the MOF but also allows adjusting the conductivity according to the desired applications.

A fit of the time-dependent data to the Cottrell equation gave a charge-transport diffusion coefficient of 1.6 × 10-10 cm2/s throughout the structure. This novel approach not only enhances the conductivity of the MOF but also allows adjusting the conductivity according to the desired applications.

elements.content: Is it possible to combine the conductivity and crystallinity of inorganic conductors with simple synthesis and diversity of organic materials? Whereas inorganic conductors are at the heart of modern electronics industry, and organic conductors have a wide variety, metal–organic frameworks can be the key to the puzzle. MOFs are crystalline nanoporous materials, and their supramolecular structure is derived from the interaction between metal ions and organic ligands. The highly ordered self-assembled organic–inorganic hybrids have a high potential for a wide range of applications. The unique properties, porosity, and designability of the MOFs in nanometer dimensions provide a very high potential for today’s electronics industry applications. Unfortunately, most of the MOFs have poor conductivity in the absence of low-energy pathways for charge transfer and free charge carriers (in most cases low conductivities in the range of <10–10 S cm–1). This nonconductivity is due to the insulation nature of the organic ligands used and the ineffective π orbital overlap of the linker groups and the metal d orbitals. To date, some strategies have proposed introduction of adequate levels of conductivity in metal–organic frameworks such as use of specific linkers, incorporation of guest molecules, doping with redoxactive compounds, and hybridization with conducting polymers. Use of specific linkers such as H4DSBDC (thiolated analogue of 2,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid) and HITP (2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene) to achieve a conductive structure are reported, especially about two-dimensional MOFs. Loading with conducting polymers also is a common method to enhance the conductivity. For example, Cr-MIL-101/PEDOT composite could create an electrical conductivity of 10–1 S m–1, much larger than that of pristine Cr-MIL-101 (10–9 S m–1). However, the existence of vacant pores makes the MOFs exciting platforms for loading the guest molecules. These guest species can be introduced during synthesis itself, or via postsynthetic modification (PSM). Different categories of dopants that have been proposed over the years include redox active molecules (e.g., TCNQ), metal oxides, metal nanoclusters, conducting polymers, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and cationic species. Filling the pores of MOFs with conducting materials can compromise their porosity. However, incorporating the metal nanoclusters (NCs) inside MOFs both supported the charge transfer and helped maintain the porosity of the framework. For example, metal deposition within structure pores by 48 h of immersion of Rb-CD-MOF in AgNO3 solution has improved the amount of conductivity (3.1 × 10–9 S cm–1). Importing quantum dots like CdS and ZnO with methods such as infiltration or encapsulation is also effective for improving the electrical properties of MOFs but often faces problems such as high heat demand, guest attraction only on external surfaces of host, inconsistent distribution, and full occupancy of the pores. These results along with the tunable functions of MOFs in selective sorption of target metal ions at appropriate sites suggested that the use of designed MOF for metal ion sorption, in addition to maintaining structural porosity, could optimally improve their conductivity. The selected MOF is better to contain electroactive metal nodes, conjugated ligands, and optimal pore size to the sorption of selected metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Is it possible to combine the conductivity and crystallinity of inorganic conductors with simple synthesis and diversity of organic materials? Whereas inorganic conductors are at the heart of modern electronics industry, and organic conductors have a wide variety, metal-organic frameworks can be the key to the puzzle. MOFs are crystalline nanoporous materials, and their supramolecular structure is derived from the interaction between metal ions and organic ligands. The highly ordered self-assembled organic-inorganic hybrids have a high potential for a wide range of applications. The unique properties, porosity, and designability of the MOFs in nanometer dimensions provide a very high potential for today's electronics industry applications. Unfortunately, most of the MOFs have poor conductivity in the absence of low-energy pathways for charge transfer and free charge carriers (in most cases low conductivities in the range of <10-10 S cm-1). This nonconductivity is due to the insulation nature of the organic ligands used and the ineffective π orbital overlap of the linker groups and the metal d orbitals. To date, some strategies have proposed introduction of adequate levels of conductivity in metal-organic frameworks such as use of specific linkers, incorporation of guest molecules, doping with redoxactive compounds, and hybridization with conducting polymers. Use of specific linkers such as H4DSBDC (thiolated analogue of 2,5-dihydroxybenzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid) and HITP (2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene) to achieve a conductive structure are reported, especially about two-dimensional MOFs. Loading with conducting polymers also is a common method to enhance the conductivity. For example, Cr-MIL-101/PEDOT composite could create an electrical conductivity of 10-1 S m-1, much larger than that of pristine Cr-MIL-101 (10-9 S m-1). However, the existence of vacant pores makes the MOFs exciting platforms for loading the guest molecules. These guest species can be introduced during synthesis itself, or via postsynthetic modification (PSM). Different categories of dopants that have been proposed over the years include redox active molecules (e.g., TCNQ), metal oxides, metal nanoclusters, conducting polymers, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and cationic species. Filling the pores of MOFs with conducting materials can compromise their porosity. However, incorporating the metal nanoclusters (NCs) inside MOFs both supported the charge transfer and helped maintain the porosity of the framework. For example, metal deposition within structure pores by 48 h of immersion of Rb-CD-MOF in AgNO3 solution has improved the amount of conductivity (3.1 × 10-9 S cm-1). Importing quantum dots like CdS and ZnO with methods such as infiltration or encapsulation is also effective for improving the electrical properties of MOFs but often faces problems such as high heat demand, guest attraction only on external surfaces of host, inconsistent distribution, and full occupancy of the pores. These results along with the tunable functions of MOFs in selective sorption of target metal ions at appropriate sites suggested that the use of designed MOF for metal ion sorption, in addition to maintaining structural porosity, could optimally improve their conductivity. The selected MOF is better to contain electroactive metal nodes, conjugated ligands, and optimal pore size to the sorption of selected metal ions.

elements.content: Cadmium is an electroactive metal with significant properties that is used extensively in batteries. Whenever the names of inorganic conductors and semiconductors are implied, ZnO and CdS are the most important species. On the other hand, surface area and particle size also have a significant effect on their performance. All of the observations led us to design a Cd sorbent of zinc based MOF that simultaneously has medium sized pores (not very big), Zn–O connections, Cd–S or Cd–N interactions, and organic ligands containing the π linkage.

elements.content: To date, cadmium sorbent MOFs have been reported rarely or associated with shortcomings such as low uptake capacity, nonselective sorption, moderate affinity for Cd­(II), or needing a long time for sorption. Meanwhile, 177 mg·g–1 of Cd­(II) sorption capacity over 2 h by UiO-66-NH2 indicates the ability of the amine group for cadmium ion sorption, which led us to the choice of amine agent as the sorbent species of the framework.

Meanwhile, 177 mg⋅g-1 of Cd(II) sorption capacity over 2 h by UiO-66-NH2 indicates the ability of the amine group for cadmium ion sorption, which led us to the choice of amine agent as the sorbent species of the framework.

elements.content: Herein, we report an effective strategy to realize tunable conductivity in metal–organic frameworks by converting an insulator MOF into a conductor. This approach is demonstrated by designing an effective sorbent MOF (TMU-60) for incorporating well-dispersed Cd­(II) in the structure. The unexpected increase of TMU-60 conductivity and reduction of charge transfer resistance by Cd­(II) penetration indicates a significant effect of Cd ions on enhancing the conductivity of the structure. The appropriate placement of cadmium ion in TMU-60 pores can compensate for the inability of the framework to communicate electrons among its constituents. Fast electron transfer capability was confirmed by the K3Fe­(CN)6 redox process even to 10 mM concentration.

elements.content: With the aim of increasing the conductivity through cadmium ion sorption by a framework and simultaneously exploiting the effects of Zn–O and Cd–N interactions and π orbitals of ligand, we designed a Zn-based framework that has a site for the Cd­(II) sorption and contains organic ligands with π orbitals. The use of functionalized pillared MOF with functional groups such as amine and thiol to remove Hg­(II) from water is well-known. Considering that Cd­(II) is classified as mercury in the category of soft metals, the design of an amine-containing framework will be effective for its selective sorption. The in situ synthesis of [Zn­(OBA)­(L*)]·DMF (TMU-60) which contains primary amine is carried out by interactions of Zn­(NO3)2, 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoic acid) (H2OBA), and 5,6-di­(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrazine ligand (L*). The L* is synthesized by in situ CC coupling reaction of N1,N2-bis­(pyridin-4-ylmethylene)­ethane-1,2-diamine (L). It was found that such aldimine coupling reactions could be catalyzed by cyanide ion but gave CC coupled products. In fact, the cyanide-catalyzed aldimine coupled product is the nitrogen analogue of benzoin condensation, which was first reported by Strain in 1928. Some other studies are reported that NaCN and K2CO3 act as catalysts for the coupling reaction. In the synthesis of L* ligand, the proposed mechanism for CC coupling is an electrophilic attack and proton-transfer process, as shown in . The L* was an intermediate, because a similar reaction occurring with an oxidant gave a six-membered ring with CN and CC bonds, which indicated that NH bonds in L* could be further oxidized. Meanwhile, because of the absence of oxygen in the autoclave, the intermediate product (L*) was obtained rather than the oxidized one (5,6-dipyridin-4-yl-2,3-dihydropyrazine). Single crystal X-ray analysis showed that the TMU-60 crystallized in space group Ibca which built up from a Zn2(COO)4 paddle-wheel secondary building units, in which each Zn atoms are connected to four oxygen and one nitrogen atom of the pillar. Two-dimensional square grid sheets, resulting from the bridging of the H2OBA carboxylate ligand and metal nodes, are broadened in three dimensions by interaction with the L* ligand. The two-fold interpenetrated structure of TMU-60 creates one-dimensional channels along the axis “a” of crystallography, so that amine-functions (highlighted as yellow balls) have an appropriate orientation for interacting with guests (). Free DMF molecules stack in TMU-60 pores orderly and are easily removed by immersing the framework in the CH2Cl2 solvent. The average distances of metalO and metalN in the TMU-60 structure are 2.04 and 2.02 Å, respectively. Lattice parameters, data collection, and refinement parameters of the framework are summarized in , and selected bond distances and bond angles presented in .
elements.clean_text:
Result and Discussion

With the aim of increasing the conductivity through cadmium ion sorption by a framework and simultaneously exploiting the effects of Zn-O and Cd-N interactions and π orbitals of ligand, we designed a Zn-based framework that has a site for the Cd(II) sorption and contains organic ligands with π orbitals. The use of functionalized pillared MOF with functional groups such as amine and thiol to remove Hg(II) from water is well-known. Considering that Cd(II) is classified as mercury in the category of soft metals, the design of an amine-containing framework will be effective for its selective sorption. The in situ synthesis of [Zn(OBA)(L*)]⋅DMF (TMU-60) which contains primary amine is carried out by interactions of Zn(NO3)2, 4,4'-oxybis(benzoic acid) (H2OBA), and 5,6-di(pyridin-4-yl)-1,2,3,4-tetrahydropyrazine ligand (L*). The L* is synthesized by in situ CC coupling reaction of N1,N2-bis(pyridin-4-ylmethylene)ethane-1,2-diamine (L). It was found that such aldimine coupling reactions could be catalyzed by cyanide ion but gave CC coupled products. In fact, the cyanide-catalyzed aldimine coupled product is the nitrogen analogue of benzoin condensation, which was first reported by Strain in 1928. Some other studies are reported that NaCN and K2CO3 act as catalysts for the coupling reaction. In the synthesis of L* ligand, the proposed mechanism for CC coupling is an electrophilic attack and proton-transfer process, as shown in . The L* was an intermediate, because a similar reaction occurring with an oxidant gave a six-membered ring with CN and CC bonds, which indicated that NH bonds in L* could be further oxidized. Meanwhile, because of the absence of oxygen in the autoclave, the intermediate product (L*) was obtained rather than the oxidized one (5,6-dipyridin-4-yl-2,3-dihydropyrazine). Single crystal X-ray analysis showed that the TMU-60 crystallized in space group Ibca which built up from a Zn2(COO)4 paddle-wheel secondary building units, in which each Zn atoms are connected to four oxygen and one nitrogen atom of the pillar. Two-dimensional square grid sheets, resulting from the bridging of the H2OBA carboxylate ligand and metal nodes, are broadened in three dimensions by interaction with the L* ligand. The two-fold interpenetrated structure of TMU-60 creates one-dimensional channels along the axis "a" of crystallography, so that amine-functions (highlighted as yellow balls) have an appropriate orientation for interacting with guests (). The average distances of metalO and metalN in the TMU-60 structure are 2.04 and 2.02 Å, respectively. Lattice parameters, data collection, and refinement parameters of the framework are summarized in , and selected bond distances and bond angles presented in .

elements.content: TGA studies reveal that the framework loses the solvent trapped inside the pores (calculated 11.51%, found 11%) in the temperature range 100–250 °C and the framework has thermal stability up to 270 °C (). Permanent porosity analysis of the structure by BET studies showed a surface area of 171.522 m2·g–1 and an adsorption capacity of 65 cm3·g–1 N2 (). Heating the frame for 12 h up to 250 °C and the stability of the XRD pattern and the BET value confirm the thermal stability of the TMU-60.

elements.content: In order to evaluate the cadmium ion uptake ability of TMU-60, the activated sample was used for metallic ion sorption. The 15 mg of sorbent was immersed in 50 mL of 50 ppm of Cd­(NO3)2 aqueous solution and was stirred at a rate of 200 rpm for 10 min. The sorbent was then separated by centrifugation and washed with water to remove unsorbed Cd­(II). The sample after sorption, called TMU-60-Cd, was subjected to IR, UV, and ICP analysis. The remaining solution was also subjected to ICP analysis to determine the amount of nonadsorbed Cd. The ICP results for TMU-60-Cd indicate a ratio of about 1.5 to 1 for Zn/Cd, which is consistent with the results obtained for the remaining solution and shows a value of 155 mg·g–1 sorption capacity of Cd­(II) by TMU-60. Complete kinetic and thermodynamic studies were carried out on the sorption process, which confirms the second-order sorption kinetics, Langmuir isotherm, and negative ΔG for the sorption process (). Also, the selectivity of sorption in the presence of other background metal ions such as Hg­(II), Pb­(II), Cd­(II), Zn­(II), Co­(II), Cr­(II), Fe­(II), and Ca­(II) showed that the TMU-60, even in the presence of other metal ions, remains a selective cadmium sorbent and other metals do not interfere in its selective action (). Although the study of Cd­(II) selective sorbents and sensors shows that nitrogen-containing groups are the best group for this purpose, the selective sorption of TMU-60 to Cd­(II) can be considered as a synergistic effect between the active sites and the pore size and morphology. The study of the pH effect on sorption capacity indicates that the highest sorption capacity is acquired in the pH of the reaction medium and the sorption process does not require pH adjustment (B). The TMU-60 reaches over 90% of its sorption capacity in less than 10 min, which is a remarkable record among all of the Cd­(II) sorbent. In order to investigate the sorption mechanism governing the sorption process and to determine whether the sorption mechanism is controlled by a chemical or physical mechanism, conventional sorption kinetics models such as pseudo-first-order, pseudo-second-order, and intraparticle diffusion are used to study the experimental data. The correlation coefficient of the pseudo-second-order model for Cd­(II) is close to 1 (R 2 = 0.9999) and exhibited that the pseudo-second-order model is more consistent with experimental data than the other model. Therefore, it is compatible with chemical sorption, which indicates that transfer, exchange, or sharing of electrons has taken place. Therefore, supramolecular interactions between cadmium ion and the free electrons of ligand nitrogens and the electrostatic interaction between the cation and the dipole of nitrogen on the dihydropyrazine ring of ligand are proposed as the dominant interactions between the metal ion and the structure. The thermodynamic parameters studied in the temperature range 288–323 K are presented in . The positive changes of enthalpy (ΔH = +3.9 kJ mol–1) for Cd­(II) sorption over TMU-60 confirmed that the sorption was endothermic in accord with the increasing sorption capacity associated with increasing sorption temperature. The entropy change, ΔS, was +15.8 J·mol–1·K–1. The low positive value of ΔS for the sorption of Cd­(II) by TMU-60 indicated a little loss of order which is common during the metal ion sorption. The positive ΔS means the increased randomness with Cd­(II) sorption. That is probably because the number of desorbed water molecules is larger than that of the adsorbed Cd­(II) molecules. The free energies of sorption at 15, 25, 35, and 55 °C are −4.91, −7.09, −8.43, and −9.78 kJ mol–1, respectively. The negative free energies confirmed that sorption was spontaneous under the experimental conditions. Therefore, the driving force of Cd­(II) sorption (negative ΔG) on TMU-60 is due to an entropy effect (positive ΔS) rather than an enthalpy change (ΔH positive). It should be noted that TMU-60, due to its considerable sorption capacity, is the fastest Cd­(II) sorbent among all MOFs ().

elements.content: IR studies before and after Cd­(II) sorption by TMU-60 are presented in . The changes in the position of some characteristic bands at 3245, 1575, and 1375 cm–1 after the sorption process which respectively are related to stretching and bending vibrations of N–H and aromatic amines indicate the involvement of amine in the Cd­(II) sorption. In addition, the presence of a shoulder at 1622 cm–1 is attributed to the vibration of nitrogen atoms that formed a coordination bond with heavy metal ions. However, the XPS analysis was performed to determine the exact location of cadmium ion in TMU-60-Cd. The presence of cadmium and its interaction with nitrogen atoms of L* ligand are shown in . To explore the possible mechanism for such Cd2+ sorption, N 1s and Cd 3d X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) studies were carried out on TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd. As illustrated in , after Cd­(II) sorption, new peaks have appeared in the XPS spectrum which can be attributed to the Cd 3d. The N 1s peak from free amine nitrogen atoms at 399.5 eV in TMU-60 is shifted to 406.2 eV on the TMU-60-Cd, indicating the weak binding between Cd2+ and amine nitrogen atoms in TMU-60-Cd. Also, significant reduction in N2 adsorption of TMU-60-Cd in comparison with TMU-60 confirms the presence of cadmium within the framework pores ().

elements.content: After making sure of the sorption capability of cadmium ions by TMU-60, an electrode previously designed to measure the electrochemical properties of the MOFs was employed (). The electrode has a hole with a radius of 2.5 mm and 4 mm depth. The hole was filled with 10 mg of grinded activated TMU-60 that is mixed with 1 mg of PVDF to achieve adhesion. The prepared mixture is compressed into the electrode hole and then immersed in the desired solution to measure the electrical conductivity of the structure. The MOF cut off the connection between the copper wire and the solution. shows the impedance diagrams of the electrode filled with TMU-60 before and after the sorption process. The complete transformation of an insulator into a conductor is clearly evident through comparing the electrochemical behavior of TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd.

elements.content: The results showed that the presence of Cd­(II) in the structure can dramatically increase conductivity, but can the conductivity be adjusted? To track this issue, an unprecedented method of fluorescence and electrochemical monitoring based on the time of ion penetration into the pores was employed. Increasing the intensity of the MOF emission spectra by increasing the amounts of cadmium ion shows that TMU-60 acts as a Cd­(II) turn-on sensor (A).
elements.clean_text:
Sensing and Interpenetration Studies

The results showed that the presence of Cd(II) in the structure can dramatically increase conductivity, but can the conductivity be adjusted? To track this issue, an unprecedented method of fluorescence and electrochemical monitoring based on the time of ion penetration into the pores was employed. Increasing the intensity of the MOF emission spectra by increasing the amounts of cadmium ion shows that TMU-60 acts as a Cd(II) turn-on sensor (A).

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the emission peak of TMU-60 in the presence of cadmium ion shifts toward higher wavelengths, which facilitates identification. The selective detection of the framework was carried out in the presence of a mixture of 50 ppm of some metal ions (B). Therefore, TMU-60 is a ratiometric fluorescent chemosensor of Cd­(II) which does not interfere with any other metal ions. The interaction of Cd­(II) with the amine function of the framework, which has already been shown by structural studies with sorption studies, can cause a redshift of fluorescence spectra. The emergence of the new peak in the UV–vis spectrum indicates the complex formation (). For penetration monitoring, the fluorescence spectra were recorded at different times from the exposure of the sorbent to the 50 ppm aqueous solution of Cd­(II). The time-dependent results in C illustrate the penetration of guest on pores and interactions with the framework. After 10 min, the fluorescence intensity which indicates the penetration, sorption, and interaction of ions with the structure depends only on the concentration of the solution. On the basis of these observations, the effect of step-by-step Cd­(II) penetration within the framework can be studied on its conductivity.

elements.content: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used as a powerful technique to study the electrochemical behavior of Cd­(II) penetration into TMU-60 pores and its effect on increasing the conductivity of the MOF. Generally, the Nyquist diagrams consist of three distinct sections: the first arc, which refers to the electrolyte penetration to the substrate; the second arc, which demonstrates the resistance of charge transfer; and a line with a 45° angle related to entering the Warburg region (impedance indicates resistor to the mass transfer, e.g., control of infiltration). As shown in , first row, the impedances time-dependent results of Cd­(II) penetration were divided into three categories. In A-1, which shows the early moments of the penetration, the amount of resistivity is so high, providing charge transfer resistance of about 56,500 Ω. With the passage of time and the sorption of most cadmium ions, the diameter of the second arc decreases rapidly, which clearly indicates a decrease in the charge transfer resistance and dominance of the mass control to kinetic control over the process (B-1). In C-1, due to the complete sorption of Cd­(II) in the pores of the TMU-60, the electron transfer paths within the framework are fully activated, the second arc has disappeared, and the electron transfer resistance has reached zero. The emergence of the Warburg impedance in low frequencies represents the domination of the mass control and the very high speed of electron transfer within the TMU-60-Cd. The Bode-phase and Bode-magnitude diagrams also confirm the aforementioned results (, second row). For a better understanding of the behavior of the penetration process, the obtained Nyquist diagrams for modeling the electrochemical process were fitted using the ZView software. The equivalent circuits shown in , third row, consist of electrolyte solution resistance (R s), MOF constant phase element (CPEM), MOF resistance (R M), double layer capacitance (CPEdl), charge transfer resistance (R ct), and Warburg impedance (W). To acquire satisfactory results from fitting of impedance data, replacement of the capacitor (C) with a constant phase element (CPE) is required. The most widely accepted description for using CPE in the electrical equivalent circuits is the microscopic roughness of solid electrodes, which causes an inhomogeneous distribution of double layer capacitance.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Studies

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used as a powerful technique to study the electrochemical behavior of Cd(II) penetration into TMU-60 pores and its effect on increasing the conductivity of the MOF. Generally, the Nyquist diagrams consist of three distinct sections: the first arc, which refers to the electrolyte penetration to the substrate; the second arc, which demonstrates the resistance of charge transfer; and a line with a 45° angle related to entering the Warburg region (impedance indicates resistor to the mass transfer, e.g., control of infiltration). As shown in , first row, the impedances time-dependent results of Cd(II) penetration were divided into three categories. In A-1, which shows the early moments of the penetration, the amount of resistivity is so high, providing charge transfer resistance of about 56,500 Ω. With the passage of time and the sorption of most cadmium ions, the diameter of the second arc decreases rapidly, which clearly indicates a decrease in the charge transfer resistance and dominance of the mass control to kinetic control over the process (B-1). In C-1, due to the complete sorption of Cd(II) in the pores of the TMU-60, the electron transfer paths within the framework are fully activated, the second arc has disappeared, and the electron transfer resistance has reached zero. The emergence of the Warburg impedance in low frequencies represents the domination of the mass control and the very high speed of electron transfer within the TMU-60-Cd. The Bode-phase and Bode-magnitude diagrams also confirm the aforementioned results (, second row). For a better understanding of the behavior of the penetration process, the obtained Nyquist diagrams for modeling the electrochemical process were fitted using the ZView software. The equivalent circuits shown in , third row, consist of electrolyte solution resistance (R s), MOF constant phase element (CPEM), MOF resistance (R M), double layer capacitance (CPEdl), charge transfer resistance (R ct), and Warburg impedance (W). To acquire satisfactory results from fitting of impedance data, replacement of the capacitor (C) with a constant phase element (CPE) is required. The most widely accepted description for using CPE in the electrical equivalent circuits is the microscopic roughness of solid electrodes, which causes an inhomogeneous distribution of double layer capacitance.

elements.content: As shown in , R M remains almost unchanged during the process, indicating the stability of the structure, but R ct decreases as ions penetrate and enters the Warburg region at low frequencies. The values of R M and R ct in equivalent circuits of fitted in the Nyquist diagrams are presented in . The open circuit potential and charge transfer resistance change vs exposed time to Cd­(II) are shown in . A rapid evolution to fewer values, from 40 to −6 mV after 20 min of immersion, and its stability at −6 mV for additional times indicates the completion of Cd­(II) sorption in the MOF structure after 20 min without any appreciable leaching. In other words, the presence of Cd­(II) ions accelerates the transport of electrons through the structure. In other words, also, the proper placement of cadmium ions among the metal and organic ligands of the framework facilitates the transfer of electrons. On the basis of observations and the TMU-60 structural arrangement, a pathway marked in yellow in the TMU-60 structure is suggested as a suitable path for electron transfer ( and ).

elements.content: To prove the electron conductivity and rule out the possibility of the ion conductivity, I–V measurements on a dry pellet of pristine and Cd2+ adsorbed MOF with activated dry pellets were done. The small size and morphology of the TMU-60 crystals make them unsuitable for single-crystal measurements. Therefore, we performed the electrical measurements in a pressed pellet of the polycrystalline material. For this purpose, two pressed pellets were prepared: (A) activated pristine TMU-60 and (B) TMU-60-Cd (both pellets were stored at 200 °C for 4 h after preparation). The sheet electrical resistance values were measured using a conventional four-probe measurement with the pellets (1 cm in diameter and 0.2 mm in thickness) at room temperature. The probes were in a straight line; the initial and final probes are used as a source of current and the others are used to measure the voltage. As shown in , the Cd2+ sorption led to marked increases in current, with a linear I–V curve. Also, the conductivity has been improved from 53 × 10–6 to 1.8 × 10–2 S·cm–1 for TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd compressed pellets, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Direct Current I-V Measurement

To prove the electron conductivity and rule out the possibility of the ion conductivity, I-V measurements on a dry pellet of pristine and Cd2+ adsorbed MOF with activated dry pellets were done. The small size and morphology of the TMU-60 crystals make them unsuitable for single-crystal measurements. Therefore, we performed the electrical measurements in a pressed pellet of the polycrystalline material. For this purpose, two pressed pellets were prepared: (A) activated pristine TMU-60 and (B) TMU-60-Cd (both pellets were stored at 200 °C for 4 h after preparation). The sheet electrical resistance values were measured using a conventional four-probe measurement with the pellets (1 cm in diameter and 0.2 mm in thickness) at room temperature. The probes were in a straight line; the initial and final probes are used as a source of current and the others are used to measure the voltage. As shown in , the Cd2+ sorption led to marked increases in current, with a linear I-V curve. Also, the conductivity has been improved from 53 × 10-6 to 1.8 × 10-2 S⋅cm-1 for TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd compressed pellets, respectively.

elements.content: To investigate the special effect of cadmium ion on TMU-60 conductivity, the EIS measurement was performed on an electrode filled with activated TMU-60 in the presence of other metal ion solutions (Zn­(II), Co­(II), Cu­(II), and Pb­(II)) as an alternative to cadmium (for greater certainty, the ion concentration and contact time increased by 10 and 3 times, respectively, compared to cadmium). As shown in , less than 20% change is observed for the Pb­(II) adsorbed sample. The conductivity values of TMU-60 in the presence of various metal ions are presented in . This ineffectiveness can be attributed to the inefficient sorption of other mentioned metal ions by the structure.
elements.clean_text:
Study of the Effect of Other Metal Ions on TMU-60 Conductivity

To investigate the special effect of cadmium ion on TMU-60 conductivity, the EIS measurement was performed on an electrode filled with activated TMU-60 in the presence of other metal ion solutions (Zn(II), Co(II), Cu(II), and Pb(II)) as an alternative to cadmium (for greater certainty, the ion concentration and contact time increased by 10 and 3 times, respectively, compared to cadmium). As shown in , less than 20% change is observed for the Pb(II) adsorbed sample. The conductivity values of TMU-60 in the presence of various metal ions are presented in . This ineffectiveness can be attributed to the inefficient sorption of other mentioned metal ions by the structure.

elements.content: Understanding electrical transport processes in molecules is important for potential applications and fundamental research purposes. Generally, three charge transport mechanisms have been identified in MOFs: (a) through-bond conduction, (b) through-space conduction (charge delocalization of adjacent aromatic linkers), and (c) hopping transport. According to the proposed pathway for electron transport of TMU-60-Cd in , the appropriate distance between the paddlewheel nodes and the cadmium ions located on the nitrogen of L* ligand, as well as no continuous conduit of charge transfer through the Zn atoms, the hopping mechanism is the probable mechanism of charge transfer. Values of the apparent charge diffusion coefficient, D hopping, were calculated from the Cottrell equation i = nFAC D hopping π t where i is the current, n is the number of electrons, F is Faraday’s constant, A is the area of the electrode (cm2), C is the concentration of active parts in the pressed pellet (mol/cm3), and t is time (s). Here, the molar concentration is taken as an average; it was estimated as the moles of Zn and Cd from crystallography data and ICP results. When current is plotted against 1/ t , the slope is given by nFAC D hopping / π . It is important to note that the linear region in this graph is usually only valid at the early stages of a potential step. When the slope of the reduction section is solved for D hopping (), the value of 1.6 × 10–10 cm2·s–1 is obtained as the diffusion coefficient. The diffusion coefficient can be related to the microscopic rate constant, k hop, for charge transfer between neighboring redox sites by k hop = D hopping r 2 Assuming an average metal–metal distance, r (hopping distance), of 2.96 nm (center-to-center), k hop is 1827 s–1.

elements.content: To prove the fast electron transfer, the redox process of K3Fe­(CN)6 in the presence of the TMU-60-Cd electrode was carried out. As shown in , the oxidation–reduction process, even in the presence of a low concentration of 10 mM, occurs at a scan rate of 100 mV·s–1, confirming the superior electron transfer rate of the TMU-60-Cd electrode. According to the results, TMU-60 is not only a quick sorbent and fluorescence cadmium sensor, but the modified TMU-60 electrode can also be considered as an electrochemical sensing device for Cd­(II) ions. It should be noted that the XRD patterns of the framework after the conductivity process () and after the redox process of K3Fe­(CN)6 () were compared with the XRD simulated pattern of TMU-60 and remain intact. Since the comparison is done in the last step, the framework XRD pattern remains intact during all stages of the process, including activation, sorption, sensing, and also electrochemical studies. The targeted design of MOFs for the sorption of special metal ions can be a way to improve the conductivity of the materials. In addition, SEM images and EDS results from pristine and Cd2+ adsorbed MOF are presented in , which show a small amount of cadmium in the structure without significant changes in its morphology.

elements.content: The last question we wish to address is whether our approach can be generalized to other types of MOFs or porous materials which are more popular. For this purpose, four common porous materials including SBA-15, Uio-66, MIL-100 (Fe), and Hkust-1 were selected. The designed paste electrode was filled with 10 mg of activated porous materials for each test and then immersed in pure water for 1 h until the water molecules penetrated the material, and then, the EIS was measured. Afterward, the electrode was immersed in a 1000 ppm solution of cadmium ion (the concentration is 10 times more than that used for TMU-60) for 1 h (the exposure time is 3 times more than that used for TMU-60) and again the impedance study was performed. Of the four selected structures, only in the case of Uio-66, 10% increment of conductivity was observed. Additionally, the conductivity of the mentioned materials before and after treatment was measured by the four-point probe method and the values of conductivities have not changed significantly. It can be concluded that the presence of porosity without a special interaction site between the host and guest is not enough for conductivity improvement. According to the observations and proposed mechanism, the existence of suitable sites for interactions with metal ions and the proper distances between the metal node and the metal ion after the sorption process can be a key factor in the hopping of electrons through the MOFs. Subsequent studies on the design of new MOFs with the ability for sorption of special metal ions can be an effective step to overcome the low conductivity of the MOFs as a great weakness by a very simple and controllable way.

elements.content: This research provides a quick, easy, and expedient way to design MOFs with controllable conductivity and mitigate the limitations of the low conductivity of MOFs for many applications. In this method, a cadmium-sorbent Zn-based MOF (TMU-60) was designed. Kinetic and thermodynamic studies confirm the rapid, effective, and selective sorption of Cd­(II) by the framework. The ion penetration steps inside the framework pores were followed by fluorescence and electrochemical methods. The results prove that the presence of Cd­(II) strongly affects the conductivity of the framework and the conductivity has been improved from 53 × 10–6 to 1.8 × 10–2 S·cm–1 for TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd compressed pellets (room temperature), respectively. Also, by adjusting the amount of adsorbed metal ion, the conductivity of the structure can be adjusted accordingly. The incorporation well-dispersed of Cd­(II) in the MOF mitigates the structure’s inability to transfer electrons between the structure. TMU-60 could be considered as the fastest sorbent, fluorescent sensor, and even an electrochemical sensor of Cd­(II). The proposed method can be an effective step to tackle the weak conductivity of the MOFs and represents a powerful pathway toward employing this category of porous materials for electronic applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

This research provides a quick, easy, and expedient way to design MOFs with controllable conductivity and mitigate the limitations of the low conductivity of MOFs for many applications. In this method, a cadmium-sorbent Zn-based MOF (TMU-60) was designed. Kinetic and thermodynamic studies confirm the rapid, effective, and selective sorption of Cd(II) by the framework. The ion penetration steps inside the framework pores were followed by fluorescence and electrochemical methods. The results prove that the presence of Cd(II) strongly affects the conductivity of the framework and the conductivity has been improved from 53 × 10-6 to 1.8 × 10-2 S⋅cm-1 for TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd compressed pellets (room temperature), respectively. Also, by adjusting the amount of adsorbed metal ion, the conductivity of the structure can be adjusted accordingly. The incorporation well-dispersed of Cd(II) in the MOF mitigates the structure's inability to transfer electrons between the structure. TMU-60 could be considered as the fastest sorbent, fluorescent sensor, and even an electrochemical sensor of Cd(II). The proposed method can be an effective step to tackle the weak conductivity of the MOFs and represents a powerful pathway toward employing this category of porous materials for electronic applications.

elements.content: All raw materials were purchased from Merck and Aldrich Co. and were used without further purification. Distilled water was used at all stages. N1,N2-bis­(pyridin-4-ylmethylene)­ethane-1,2-diamine (L) was synthesized as described in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Methods

Materials

All raw materials were purchased from Merck and Aldrich Co. and were used without further purification. Distilled water was used at all stages. N1,N2-bis(pyridin-4-ylmethylene)ethane-1,2-diamine (L) was synthesized as described in the literature.

elements.content: The equivalent molar ratios of Zn­(NO3)2·4H2O as metal salt, 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoic acid) (H2OBA) as acidic ligand, and N1,N2-bis­(pyridin-4-ylmethylene)­ethane-1,2-diamine (L) as pillar were added to 15 mg of DMF. The mixture was heated to 60 °C to dissolve all components. The resulting yellow solution then was transferred to a Teflon autoclave and heated to 120 °C for 72 h and then was cooled down to ambient temperature over 24 h. The red crystals of TMU-60 were separated by filtration and washed with DMF and three times with ethanol to remove unreacted materials and dried in air. Yield: ∼20%. IR (KBr, cm–1) for TMU-60: 461.99, 656.61, 775.74, 837.65, 1016.40, 1075.05, 1145.28, 1225.62, 1375.15, 1494.46, 1575.20, 1606.10, 1674.15, 3245.75. Elemental analysis (%) calculated: C 59.96, H 3.56, N 6.66. Found: C 60.0, H 3.5, N 7.1.

The mixture was heated to 60 °C to dissolve all components. The resulting yellow solution then was transferred to a Teflon autoclave and heated to 120 °C for 72 h and then was cooled down to ambient temperature over 24 h. elements.content: Prior to any sorption, sensing, or electrochemical process, the solvent exchange was used to remove the solvents from the pores. For this purpose, the crystals of TMU-60 immersed in CH2Cl2 for 48 h, and every 12 h, the solvent refreshed. Afterward, they were separated by filtration and were kept at 120 °C for 24 h. As an alternative method, the crystal can be kept at 200 °C under a vacuum for 4 h.
elements.clean_text:
Activation of TMU-60

Prior to any sorption, sensing, or electrochemical process, the solvent exchange was used to remove the solvents from the pores. For this purpose, the crystals of TMU-60 immersed in CH2Cl2 for 48 h, and every 12 h, the solvent refreshed. Afterward, they were separated by filtration and were kept at 120 °C for 24 h. As an alternative method, the crystal can be kept at 200 °C under a vacuum for 4 h.

elements.content: All sorption experiments for kinetic and thermodynamic studies were carried out for single metal ion sorption by shaking 15 mg of TMU-60 into each conical flask which contained 50 mL of 50 ppm M2+ water at 400 rpm. The pH was adjusted by adding a small amount of 0.1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and 0.1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl). After an appropriate time, the mixture was centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 3 min and sampled for ICP analysis. The sorption capacity and removal efficiency (% sorption) were obtained from the equations listed below, respectively, Q t = [ ( C 0 − C t ) / M ] × V % R = [ ( C 0 − C e ) / M ] × 100 where C 0, C e, M, and V are the initial concentrations, equilibrium concentrations (mg·L–1), sorbent mass (g), and volume (L) of the sample, respectively. For sorption kinetic studies, the sorption process was paused at different times from 1 to 120 min. Also, from isotherm studies, the different initial concentrations in the range from 5 to 200 mg·L–1 were poured into a Falcon conical tube with 15.0 mg of TMU-60 and shaken for 2 h at ambient temperature. The equilibrium sorption capacity (Q e) was determined using : Q e = [ ( C 0 − C e ) / M ] × V
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for Sorption Experiments of Heavy Metal Ions

All sorption experiments for kinetic and thermodynamic studies were carried out for single metal ion sorption by shaking 15 mg of TMU-60 into each conical flask which contained 50 mL of 50 ppm M2+ water at 400 rpm. The pH was adjusted by adding a small amount of 0.1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH) and 0.1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl). After an appropriate time, the mixture was centrifuged at 10000 rpm for 3 min and sampled for ICP analysis. The sorption capacity and removal efficiency (% sorption) were obtained from the equations listed below, respectively, 3      Q   t   =  [  (   C   0   -   C   t   )  / M ]  × V     4    % R =  [  (   C   0   -   C   e   )  / M ]  × 100   where C 0, C e, M, and V are the initial concentrations, equilibrium concentrations (mg⋅L-1), sorbent mass (g), and volume (L) of the sample, respectively. For sorption kinetic studies, the sorption process was paused at different times from 1 to 120 min. Also, from isotherm studies, the different initial concentrations in the range from 5 to 200 mg⋅L-1 were poured into a Falcon conical tube with 15.0 mg of TMU-60 and shaken for 2 h at ambient temperature. The equilibrium sorption capacity (Q e) was determined using : 5      Q   e   =  [  (   C   0   -   C   e   )  / M ]  × V

elements.content: Fluorescence emission spectra of TMU-60 were measured in 4 mL of different concentrations of metal ion aqueous solutions containing 1 mg of grinded activated MOFs by a PerkinElmer-LS55 Fluorescence Spectrometer at room temperature after 15 min of sonication. In order to study selective sensing of TMU-60 to Cd­(II), separate solutions of various metal ions with 50 ppm concentration were used. For penetration studies, after the immersion of the MOF in Cd­(II) solution after the specified time, the fluorescence spectra were recorded.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Measurements

Fluorescence emission spectra of TMU-60 were measured in 4 mL of different concentrations of metal ion aqueous solutions containing 1 mg of grinded activated MOFs by a PerkinElmer-LS55 Fluorescence Spectrometer at room temperature after 15 min of sonication. In order to study selective sensing of TMU-60 to Cd(II), separate solutions of various metal ions with 50 ppm concentration were used. For penetration studies, after the immersion of the MOF in Cd(II) solution after the specified time, the fluorescence spectra were recorded.

cln_elements.content: The equivalent molar ratios of Zn­(NO3)2·4H2O as metal salt, 4,4′-oxybis­(benzoic acid) (H2OBA) as acidic ligand, and N1,N2-bis­(pyridin-4-ylmethylene)­ethane-1,2-diamine (L) as pillar were added to 15 mg of DMF. The mixture was heated to 60 °C to dissolve all components. The resulting yellow solution then was transferred to a Teflon autoclave and heated to 120 °C for 72 h and then was cooled down to ambient temperature over 24 h. The red crystals of TMU-60 were separated by filtration and washed with DMF and three times with ethanol to remove unreacted materials and dried in air. Yield: ∼20%. IR (KBr, cm–1) for TMU-60: 461.99, 656.61, 775.74, 837.65, 1016.40, 1075.05, 1145.28, 1225.62, 1375.15, 1494.46, 1575.20, 1606.10, 1674.15, 3245.75. cln_elements.content:
This study has developed a simple and innovative approach to design a metal–organic framework (MOF) with tunable conductivity. The in situ amine functionalized TMU-60 [Zn­(OBA)­(L*)·DMF] has the potential of converting to a conductor due to the selective and fast sorption of cadmium ion. In order to precisely monitor the cadmium penetration to the framework pores, in addition to full kinetic and thermodynamic studies of sorption, the time-dependent effects of Cd­(II) penetration to MOF pores was taken by fluorescence and electrochemical methods. The results obviously prove that the conductivity of the structure can be adjusted by changing the Cd exposure time and the quantity of ion sorption. The presence of cadmium ions can enhance the ability of the framework to pass electrons through its constituents. Even though the porosity of the structure remains to a certain extent, the achieved tunable and highly stable electrical conductivity is provided by sorption of metal ions. More importantly, the conductivity has been improved from 53 × 10–6 to 1.8 × 10–2 S·cm–1 for TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd compressed pellet (room temperature), respectively. The mechanism of charge transport through the pellet is proposed to be a hopping mechanism between metal nodes and localized Cd­(II) after sorption, which is supported by chronoamperometry measurement. A fit of the time-dependent data to the Cottrell equation gave a charge-transport diffusion coefficient of 1.6 × 10–10 cm2/s throughout the structure. This novel approach not only enhances the conductivity of the MOF but also allows adjusting the conductivity according to the desired applications.

To date, cadmium sorbent MOFs have been reported rarely or associated with shortcomings such as low uptake capacity, nonselective sorption, moderate affinity for Cd­(II), or needing a long time for sorption. Meanwhile, 177 mg·g–1 of Cd­(II) sorption capacity over 2 h by UiO-66-NH2 indicates the ability of the amine group for cadmium ion sorption, which led us to the choice of amine agent as the sorbent species of the framework.

TGA studies reveal that the framework loses the solvent trapped inside the pores (calculated 11.51%, found 11%) in the temperature range 100–250 °C and the framework has thermal stability up to 270 °C (). Permanent porosity analysis of the structure by BET studies showed a surface area of 171.522 m2·g–1 and an adsorption capacity of 65 cm3·g–1 N2 (). Heating the frame for 12 h up to 250 °C and the stability of the XRD pattern and the BET value confirm the thermal stability of the TMU-60.

This study has developed a simple and innovative approach to design a metal-organic framework (MOF) with tunable conductivity. The in situ amine functionalized TMU-60 [Zn(OBA)(L*)⋅DMF] has the potential of converting to a conductor due to the selective and fast sorption of cadmium ion. In order to precisely monitor the cadmium penetration to the framework pores, in addition to full kinetic and thermodynamic studies of sorption, the time-dependent effects of Cd(II) penetration to MOF pores was taken by fluorescence and electrochemical methods. The results obviously prove that the conductivity of the structure can be adjusted by changing the Cd exposure time and the quantity of ion sorption. The presence of cadmium ions can enhance the ability of the framework to pass electrons through its constituents. Even though the porosity of the structure remains to a certain extent, the achieved tunable and highly stable electrical conductivity is provided by sorption of metal ions. More importantly, the conductivity has been improved from 53 × 10-6 to 1.8 × 10-2 S⋅cm-1 for TMU-60 and TMU-60-Cd compressed pellet (room temperature), respectively. The mechanism of charge transport through the pellet is proposed to be a hopping mechanism between metal nodes and localized Cd(II) after sorption, which is supported by chronoamperometry measurement. A fit of the time-dependent data to the Cottrell equation gave a charge-transport diffusion coefficient of 1.6 × 10-10 cm2/s throughout the structure. This novel approach not only enhances the conductivity of the MOF but also allows adjusting the conductivity according to the desired applications.

To date, cadmium sorbent MOFs have been reported rarely or associated with shortcomings such as low uptake capacity, nonselective sorption, moderate affinity for Cd(II), or needing a long time for sorption. Meanwhile, 177 mg⋅g-1 of Cd(II) sorption capacity over 2 h by UiO-66-NH2 indicates the ability of the amine group for cadmium ion sorption, which led us to the choice of amine agent as the sorbent species of the framework. 

TGA studies reveal that the framework loses the solvent trapped inside the pores (calculated 11.51%, found 11%) in the temperature range 100-250 °C and the framework has thermal stability up to 270 °C (). Permanent porosity analysis of the structure by BET studies showed a surface area of 171.522 m2⋅g-1 and an adsorption capacity of 65 cm3⋅g-1 N2 ().
